title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as Laci and Conner's Law, amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter, "Protection of Unborn Children," which outlines measures for the protection of unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as Laci and Conner's Law, introduces a new chapter in Title 18 of the United States Code to protect unborn children. The law establishes a separate offense for causing harm or death to a child in utero, with penalties similar to those for harming the mother. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for causing harm or death to an unborn child. If the person intentionally kills the unborn child, they will be punished under specific sections of the law. The death penalty cannot be imposed for offenses under this section. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for causing harm or death to an unborn child. The death penalty shall not be imposed for an offense under this section. The specific provisions referred to in subsection (a) include various sections of the law related to different offenses. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes penalties for harming or causing death to an unborn child. The Act clarifies that prosecution is not permitted for conduct related to abortion with consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or for any woman with respect to her unborn child. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 defines an "unborn child" as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in utero. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 defines an "unborn child" as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in utero. Section 3 of the Military Justice System includes protection for unborn children under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. Any person subject to the Military Justice System who violates certain laws causing harm to an unborn child in utero will face a separate offense and punishment determined by a court-martial. Proof of harm to the mother is not required for this offense. An offense under this section does not require proof of knowledge about the victim's pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child. If the conduct results in the intentional killing or attempted killing of the unborn child, the person will be punished under specific sections for intentionally killing a human being. The death penalty cannot be imposed for intentionally killing a human being under this section. Prosecution is not permitted for conduct related to abortion with proper consent. The text chunk discusses the definition of an "unborn child" as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development. It also includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections in the subchapter. The curr_chunk discusses the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
